Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Collaborative Research: Algorithmic Approaches to Energy-Efficient Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Energy consumption is now emerging as a dominant performance measure in computer systems. In recent years, significant progress in improving energy efficiency has been accomplished by a combination of better hardware design and software tools. Yet the design of future energy-efficient computer systems will ultimately require the development of fundamental models and algorithmic tools that can be used to guide practical solutions.

This project is to study algorithmic methods for improving energy efficiency of data processing and storage in computer systems. The basic approach is to model the operation of various system components in the language of combinatorial optimization, with the objective function representing energy consumption, and to solve these problems using exact or approximate efficient algorithms. Many of those problems can be formulated in terms of task scheduling, where the objective is to optimize the CPU energy consumption required to complete a collection of tasks, while meeting some performance requirements. Other examples include minimizing energy consumption of memory systems, both the internal and external memories, by optimizing power levels and sophisticated paging or caching strategies. In addition to addressing some specific energy optimization problems, this work is expected to produce new algorithmic techniques, as well as deeper understanding of the adequacy of standard performance enhancement tools, like caching and load balancing, for improving energy efficiency. The study on energy complexity will also shed some light on the relation between computation and energy.

Some algorithms developed in the course of this research will be implemented, tested empirically on the FreeBSD-based platform, and made available to practitioners. The educational component includes research projects for graduate and undergraduate students, and developing a course on sustainable computing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Energy consumption is now emerging as a dominant performance measure in computer systems. The aim of power management is to reduce the energy consumed by electrical devices while maintaining satisfactory performance. The design of energy-efficient computer systems will ultimately require the development of fundamental models and algorithmic tools that can be used to guide practical solutions.

This research is to study algorithmic methods for improving energy efficiency of data processing and storage in computer systems. The basic approach is to model the operation of various system components in the language of combinatorial optimization, with the objective function representing energy consumption, and to solve these problems using exact or approximate efficient algorithms. This work is expected to produce new algorithmic techniques and new methods to combine and enrich existing techniques. On a more fundamental level, this work will provide deeper understanding of the adequacy of standard performance enhancement tools for improving energy efficiency. The study on energy complexity will also contribute to better understanding of the relation between computation and energy.

This research will produce formal models, algorithmic techniques, and general principles in energy-efficient computing that can be used to guide real-life solutions. The educational component includes research projects for graduate and undergraduate students, and developing a course on sustainable computing.

The above research has produced around 10 publications on top journals and conferences, including: Journal of Scheduling, Sustainable Computing: Informatics and Systems, Computer Communications, and conferences such as CIAC, DSN, and ISGC. One of the PI's female Ph.D. students, Ms. Zhi Zhang, was partially supported by the above grant and has graduated and joined Google in 2013. This grant has been supported two female Ph.D. students.
